{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "How do I know if I have a poplar field cap? I have a poplar tree, that's for sure. And it's kind of growing around on the roots, sticking around in the base of the tree on the grass. Has a, you know, brown spore print. And a little stipe, I think, called a little, like, skirt, you know, that hangs on the stem. Kind of a white top with a little brown spot on it, like some brown in the middle radiating out. And some of them kind of grow in clusters, you know, like two or three out of the same base, and then some of them kind of pop up by themselves.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'It sounds like you might be describing a type of mushroom that‚Äôs often found around poplar trees, and from what you‚Äôre mentioning‚Äîlike the brown spore print and the little ring or skirt on the stem‚Äîit could be a member of the Agrocybe or something similar. They do sometimes cluster at the base of trees, especially poplars, and have those whitish caps with a bit of brown in the center.\n\nSo if you‚Äôve got that combination of a brown spore print, a ring on the stem, and they‚Äôre growing right around that poplar tree, you‚Äôre probably on the right track. Just remember to be cautious with ID if you‚Äôre thinking of foraging them. But that does sound like a common type of poplar field cap or a similar mushroom.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'OK, so what are all of the ID elements for a Poplar FieldCat?', 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2026-03-18T05:39:54.622045+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2026-03-18T05:39:54.622045+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000e4c0622f8eadd739bd36f3a9', 'size_bytes': 350478, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 7.3}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 94.44853654596955}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Sure! So if we break it down, the key identification features for a mushroom like a poplar field cap would include a few main elements. 

First, you have the habitat, which is pretty important. They grow around poplar trees, especially at the base or on decaying roots, so the fact that you‚Äôre seeing them near your poplar is a good clue.

Second, you have the cap appearance. Typically, these mushrooms have a kind of creamy to pale white cap with a little brownish or tan area in the middle that can radiate outward. Sometimes it‚Äôs more uniform, but often you get that little brownish center.

Third, the spore print is a big one. A brown spore print is a solid identifier because not all mushrooms have that color, and it helps narrow it down to a certain family.

Then you have the ring or the skirt on the stem, which is a little leftover partial veil that forms a sort of ring around the upper part of the stem.

And lastly, the growth pattern matters too. If they‚Äôre popping up in little clusters around the tree roots, that‚Äôs pretty typical.

Put all those together‚Äîhabitat, cap color, spore print, ring on the stem, and growth habit‚Äîand you‚Äôve got a pretty good set of ID markers for a poplar field cap.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

Thanks for sharing these extra photos ‚Äî they help a lot.  

From what I see:  

- The mushrooms are growing in tight clusters right at the base of a tree (looks like poplar or similar).  
- They have **whitish to cream caps**, often with a **darker tan/brownish center** that can crack or craze with age.  
- The **gills are pale, crowded, free to slightly attached**, and the spore print you mentioned earlier was **brown**.  
- There‚Äôs a **distinct ring/skirt on the stem** (you can see it clearly in the first photo).  
- The caps range from smooth when young to cracked/scaly as they expand.  

All of this matches really well with **Agrocybe aegerita** (also called *Poplar Fieldcap*, *Pioppino*), which is often found growing on or near poplar trees, in clusters like this.  

‚ö†Ô∏è **Look-alikes to be careful with:**  
- **Some Stropharia species** (darker purple-brown spore prints, sticky caps).  
- **Some small Agaricus** (but those usually have a chocolate-brown print and stronger odors).  
- **Deadly Galerina** (tends to be smaller, rusty spores, on rotting wood).  

The combination of **clustered growth on poplar roots, whitish cap with brownish center, ring on the stem, and brown spore print** strongly supports *Agrocybe aegerita*.  

üëâ Just to be safe:  
- Double-check the **spore print color** (should be medium to dark brown, not rusty or purple).  
- Make sure the ring is always present (Galerina lacks a sturdy, persistent one).  

Do you want me to make a **side-by-side comparison table** between *Agrocybe aegerita* and the most common dangerous look-alikes (like Galerina, Stropharia, Agaricus), so you can feel more confident about what you‚Äôve got?

{'content_type': 'image_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'file-service://file-R42UrpHBARzLCC6Y9bCBUn', 'size_bytes': 3901957, 'width': 1152, 'height': 1536, 'fovea': None, 'metadata': {'dalle': None, 'gizmo': None, 'generation': None, 'container_pixel_height': None, 'container_pixel_width': None, 'emu_omit_glimpse_image': None, 'emu_patches_override': None, 'lpe_keep_patch_ijhw': None, 'sanitized': True, 'asset_pointer_link': None, 'watermarked_asset_pointer': None}}
This one has the color of the spore print, and the flipped version of an aged one. One that's aged, and so it drops spores around it, on the other mushrooms.

Perfect ‚Äî this last photo really helps confirm things.  

You can clearly see:  
- **Dark brown spore deposit** dusting the caps and gills of the older mushrooms.  
- The gills aging from pale to darker brown as spores mature.  
- The mushrooms still showing that **persistent ring/skirt** on the stem.  
- Clustered growth right on the tree roots.  

That **medium-to-dark brown spore print** (not rusty-orange, not black, not purple) is a strong match for ***Agrocybe aegerita* (Pioppino / Poplar Fieldcap)**.  

This separates it from the main dangerous look-alikes:  
- **Galerina marginata** ‚Üí spore print is rusty cinnamon-brown, often more orange; smaller and fragile; deadly poisonous.  
- **Stropharia species** ‚Üí spore print purplish-brown, not this earthy brown; caps often sticky/slimy when fresh.  
- **Agaricus species** ‚Üí spore print chocolate-brown but usually darker; they also don‚Äôt grow in tight clusters directly from tree roots.  

So, with your spore print evidence + habitat (clusters on poplar) + ring + cap form, these look very consistent with *Agrocybe aegerita*.  

üëâ Would you like me to draft a **side-by-side comparison table** (Pioppino vs Galerina vs Stropharia vs Agaricus) so you have a quick-reference safety guide? That way you can double-check every key feature before making any decisions.
How to cook poplars are there other poplars?

Yes ‚Äî what you‚Äôve got are very likely *Poplar Fieldcaps* (***Agrocybe aegerita***), also known as **pioppino** in Italy. They are widely cultivated and eaten in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines.  

---

## üç≥ How to Cook Pioppino (Poplar Fieldcaps)

- **Texture & Flavor**:  
  Firm stems, tender caps, nutty, slightly peppery flavor. They stay pleasantly chewy after cooking.  

- **Basic Prep**:  
  - Brush off dirt (don‚Äôt soak in water, they absorb it).  
  - Trim the base of the cluster.  
  - Use both cap and stem (stems are tougher but flavorful).  

- **Cooking Methods**:  
  - **Saut√©**: Fry in olive oil or butter with garlic, onion, salt, and pepper until golden. Excellent base for pasta or risotto.  
  - **Soup/Stew**: Add to broths; they hold their shape and flavor.  
  - **Grill/Roast**: Whole mushrooms roasted with olive oil, salt, and herbs.  
  - **Asian-style**: Stir-fried with soy sauce, ginger, sesame oil.  

- **Pairs well with**:  
  Eggs (omelets, frittatas), pasta, risotto, polenta, grilled meats, herbs like thyme, parsley, rosemary.  

---

## üå≥ Are there ‚Äúother poplars‚Äù?  
Yes ‚Äî the name ‚Äúpoplar mushroom‚Äù is tied to *Agrocybe aegerita* because it grows on **poplar trees** (*Populus* species), but also sometimes on willow or elm.  

However, there are other mushrooms that sometimes get nicknames like ‚Äúpoplar‚Äù or ‚Äúcottonwood‚Äù mushrooms:  
- **Agrocybe cylindracea** ‚Äî sometimes treated as the same species as *aegerita*.  
- **Cyclocybe erebia** ‚Äî a close relative, darker capped, also called a ‚Äúpoplar mushroom‚Äù in some places.  
- **Cyclocybe spp.** ‚Äî several species can grow on hardwoods.  

But the main edible one cultivated worldwide is ***Agrocybe aegerita (Pioppino)***.  

---

üëâ Do you want me to put together a **few simple recipes** (like Italian-style saut√©, soup, and Asian stir-fry) specifically tailored to pioppino so you can try them out?
